Amending the Pleadings TC "III. Amending the Pleadings" \f C \l "2"  Rule 15 allows amendments to pleadings, sets out restrictions COMPLAINT can amend once, as a matter of course, before answer is served (without ct permission or agreement by opponent) note: this might amend time limits of response ANSWER can amend without ct permission or agreement by opponent under certain circumstances responsive pleading (holds a counterclaim requiring answer): can amend before answer served not a responsive pleading: can amend only within 20 days after it is served RELATING BACK assuming that filing/serving of complaint occurred within statute of limitations, can sometimes add new claim for damages that arose before time limit of statute Rule 15(c) claim can relate back to time period of statute of limitations, if it arises out of conduct set forth in original pleading Barcume v. City of Flint (original complaint pleading discrimination in hiring/promotion practices; proposed amended complaint adding allegations of hostile workplace and sexual harassment) holding: new claims did NOT arise from old ones no factual support ������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������f�o�r� �t�h�e�s�e� �c�l�a�i�m�s� �i�n� �o�r�i�g�i�n�a�l� �c�o�m�p�l�a�i�n�t� � � �h�a�d� �n�o� �n�o�t�i�c�e� �t�h�a�t� �s� �w�e�r�e� �p�u�r�s�u�i�n�g� �t�h�a�t� �p�a�r�t�i�c�u�l�a�r� �t�y�p�e� �o�f� �d�i�s�c�r�i�m�i�n�a�t�i�o�n� �c�l�a�i�m�;� �u�n�f�a�i�r� �t�o� �s� �i�n� �t�e�r�m�s� �o�f� �t�r�i�a�l� �p�r�e�p�a�r�a�t�i�o�n� �q�u�e�s�t�i�o�n� �o�f� �p�r�e�j�u�d�i�c�e� � �c�t� �w�o�r�r�i�e�s� �i�f� �o�n�e� �s�i�d�e� �h�a�s� �g�r�e�a�t�e�r� �a�d�v�a�n�t�a�g�e� �o�v�e�r� �o�t�h�e�r� � �h�o�w� �p�r�ejudiced are parties by the amended pleading? Nelson v. Adams USA Inc. (original pleading: Ohio Cellular Products sued Adams for patent infringement; ct found for Adams; Adams worried that OCP would be able to pay costs as ordered, moved to amend pleadings to name Nelson, OCP president, as a party to the action) DCt granted motion to make Nelson party, and also granted motion to subject him to the judgment holding: lower ct erred in doing so due process (as reflected in Rules 15 and 12) requires that Nelson be given opportunity to respond and contest his personal liability for the award after he was made a party and before entry of judgment against him due process doesnt allow such swift passage from pleading to judgment in pleaders favor  IV. Rule 11 as a cost-shifting device cost of litigation shifted to lawyer bringing a frivolous suit    4 DISCOVERY AND DISCLOSURE TC "4 DISCOVERY AND DISCLOSURE" \f C \l "1"  I. Discovery and Disclosure TC "I. Discovery and Disclosure" \f C \l "2"  purpose of discovery/disclosure rules how parties discover what their adversary has, in terms of witnesses, documents, evidence can force adversary to reveal things damaging to them (remarkable about American system) sizing up witnesses evaluation of possible effect on jury enables settlement parties have a better sense of what theyre up against; better strategizing lock witnesses into positions witnesses have to sign transcript under oath attrition well-moneyed parties draw out process, attempt to force settlement at discounted rate problems with discovery process promotes dispute over information access emphasizes inequality of resources (attrition strategy) depositions can sometimes lead away from the truth (confusing the witnesses; strategizing) structure of discovery rules Rule 26 scope; sets out what is discoverable 26(a) mandatory disclosure (initial disclosures, experts, witnesses) 26(b) scope of discovery (any matter (not privileged) relevant to claim/defense of any party) Rules 27-36 devices of discovery Rule 37 sanctions (both compelling and preventing discovery) distinction between mandatory disclosure and discovery (see notes p.38 for more detail) fits into broader scheme how litigation proceeds after pleadings have been exchanged discovery planning conference [26(f) conference] 26(a)(1) initial disclosures (soon after planning conference) scheduling order [16(b)] here, the judge finally gets involved in the case after all this, discovery then begins discovery = what you produce in response to request from adversary; disclosure = what you voluntarily produce in compliance with 26(a) difference between what must be disclosed and what is discoverable note: disclosures still happen later in litigation: 26(a)(3) pretrial disclosures, until 30 days before trial discoverable materials party seeking discovery must show substantial need of materials in preparation of his case must also show that he is unable without undue hardship to obtain the substantial equivalent of the materials by other means exception: work-product of attorney is protected from discovery (see privileges section below) Chalick v. Choosing a Jury" \f C \l "2"  unlimited number of strikes for cause when juror answers voir dire questions in a way that shows s/he isnt neutral/impartial ( very rare for judge to strike for cause limited number and application of peremptory strikes lawyers can choose to strike jurors as long as neutral reasons given Edmonson, J.E.B. placed constitutional limits on use of peremptory strikes must be race- and gender-neutral burden on party opposing peremptory to lodge complaint against challenge for race reason; burden on party exercising peremptory to show race-neutral reason limits on peremptories virtually meaningless smart lawyer can come up with neutral reason can peremptories ever be truly neutral? special cases of discriminatory bias singled out? J.E.B. seems to excuse biases other than race/gender other biases dont reinforce historically negative stereotypes  III. Managing the Jury TC "III. Managing the Jury" \f C \l "2"  INSTRUCTIONS TO JURY TC "INSTRUCTIONS TO JURY" \f C \l "3"  [Rule 51] at close of evidence (or as ct directs), parties may submit written requests for jury instructions; ct will inform counsel of its proposed action re: instructions before arguments before the jury no party can claim error in instructions on appeal unless they made a clear objection to the instructions prior to jury deliberation almost talismanic formulas adopted by lawyers/judges not always easily understood by juries SPECIAL VERDICTS TC "SPECIAL VERDICTS" \f C \l "3"  [Rule 49(a)] questions put to jury, each of which represent some factual element of the case jurys answer constitutes a verdict, a finding of the jury on that issue that the judge must respect (unless he need proceed no further reasonable care means no liability, no need to answer qs re: proximate cause, etc. one way of avoiding emotional reaction of juries to the big picture of the case judge-friendly rule if a party finds omission of fact in a question, each party waives the right to trial by jury of the issue so omitted (unless party demands its submission to jury before jury retires) substantial power of judge to fill in the blanks responsibility lawyers have to parse questions v. carefully before judge gives them to the jury INTERROGATORIES TO JURY TC "INTERROGATORIES TO JURY" \f C \l "3"  [Rule 49(b)] questions put to jury, always accompanied by request for jury to come back with a general verdict individual questions arent dispositive jury has to answer all of them, and also return general verdict discretion of judge when answers are inconsistent with each other or with the general verdict JUDGMENT AS A MATTER OF LAW TC "JUDGMENT AS A MATTER OF LAW" \f C \l "3"  [Rule 50] if during trial a party has been fully heard on an issue, and there is no legally sufficient evidentiary basis for a reasonable jury to find for that party on that issue, ct may determine the issue against that party, may grant judgment as a matter of law against that party on claims dependent on that issue motions for JMOL can be made at any time before submission of case to jury see CB p.742 for timeline of when parties can make JMOL motions motions must specify judgment sought and law/facts on which movant is entitled to judgment most extreme method of control takes decisional power away from jury, gives to judge if judge grants JMOL, app ct applies de novo review (no weight to what trial ct held) question before the ct is purely a matter of law; regardless of whether JMOL granted before or after jury determined issue of fact, appellate review will be the same (can decide jury got it wrong; power to review questions of law) question of constitutionality 7th A preserves right to jury trial now settled (by practice if not by history) that JMOL is constitutional under 7th A if JMOL gives judges too much power to decide facts, then its got to be unconstitutional; but if theres very little power of judge to look at facts, then rule has little utility various formulas about the point below which a party may not fall (wrt persuasiveness of evidence) clear that this analysis requires judge to weigh the evidence to some extent our system denies this, though judge/jury, law/fact distinction two types of JMOL: 50(a) after party has been ( intervening change in the law general rule against allowing 60(b) motions simply b/c there been an intervening change in the law exception: ct applies 60(b)(6) any other reason justifying relief from the operation of the judgment special circumstances: ppl in the same accident; unjust to apply different rule of law to parties in the same accident more important reason: in a diversity case, fed cts supposed to apply state law since state of OK has told us that the substantive rule has changed, fed ct should now apply new state law this case is NOT generally followed more important: stability of judgment, finality of litigation Ackerman v. US brothers-in-law joined cases of citizenship revocation; trial ct revoked citizenship; one brother appealed, one didnt; appealing brother won the appeal; other brother brought 60(b)(6) motion but was DENIED calculated risk to not appeal, so tough luck one area where exceptions allowed: where are there ongoing relationships, perhaps because of a judgment or injunction Agostini v. Amending the Pleadings TC "III. Amending the Pleadings" \f C \l "2"  Rule 15 allows amendments to pleadings, sets out restrictions COMPLAINT can amend once, as a matter of course, before answer is served (without ct permission or agreement by opponent) note: this might amend time limits of response ANSWER can amend without ct permission or agreement by opponent under certain circumstances responsive pleading (holds a counterclaim requiring answer): can amend before answer served not a responsive pleading: can amend only within 20 days after it is served RELATING BACK assuming that filing/serving of complaint occurred within statute of limitations, can sometimes add new claim for damages that arose before time limit of statute Rule 15(c) claim can relate back to time period of statute of limitations, if it arises out of conduct set forth in original pleading Barcume v. City of Flint (original complaint pleading discrimination in hiring/promotion practices; proposed amended complaint adding allegations of hostile workplace and sexual harassment) holding: new claims did NOT arise from old ones no factual support ������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������f�o�r� �t�h�e�s�e� �c�l�a�i�m�s� �i�n� �o�r�i�g�i�n�a�l� �c�o�m�p�l�a�i�n�t� � � �h�a�d� �n�o� �n�o�t�i�c�e� �t�h�a�t� �s� �w�e�r�e� �p�u�r�s�u�i�n�g� �t�h�a�t� �p�a�r�t�i�c�u�l�a�r� �t�y�p�e� �o�f� �d�i�s�c�r�i�m�i�n�a�t�i�o�n� �c�l�a�i�m�;� �u�n�f�a�i�r� �t�o� �s� �i�n� �t�e�r�m�s� �o�f� �t�r�i�a�l� �p�r�e�p�a�r�a�t�i�o�n� �q�u�e�s�t�i�o�n� �o�f� �p�r�e�j�u�d�i�c�e� � �c�t� �w�o�r�r�i�e�s� �i�f� �o�n�e� �s�i�d�e� �h�a�s� �g�r�e�a�t�e�r� �a�d�v�a�n�t�a�g�e� �o�v�e�r� �o�t�h�e�r� � �h�o�w� �p�r�ejudiced are parties by the amended pleading? Nelson v. Adams USA Inc. (original pleading: Ohio Cellular Products sued Adams for patent infringement; ct found for Adams; Adams worried that OCP would be able to pay costs as ordered, moved to amend pleadings to name Nelson, OCP president, as a party to the action) DCt granted motion to make Nelson party, and also granted motion to subject him to the judgment holding: lower ct erred in doing so due process (as reflected in Rules 15 and 12) requires that Nelson be given opportunity to respond and contest his personal liability for the award after he was made a party and before entry of judgment against him due process doesnt allow such swift passage from pleading to judgment in pleaders favor  IV. Counterclaims" \f C \l "2"  Rule 13 permissive counterclaims [13(b)] very broad rule; no real restrictions on permissive counterclaims any claim NOT arising out of transaction/occurrence of original claim assumes 13(a) compulsory counterclaims [13(a)] must be stated in the pleading if: it arises out of the transaction that is the subject matter of the opposing partys claim, and does not require presence of third parties over whom ct cant get jurisdiction subject-matter jurisdiction compulsory counterclaims fall within supplemental jurisdiction of fed cts (fed ct can hear claim even if no Discovery and Disclosure" \f C \l "2"  purpose of discovery/disclosure rules how parties discover what their adversary has, in terms of witnesses, documents, evidence can force adversary to reveal things damaging to them (remarkable about American system) sizing up witnesses evaluation of possible effect on jury enables settlement parties have a better sense of what theyre up against; better strategizing lock witnesses into positions witnesses have to sign transcript under oath attrition well-moneyed parties draw out process, attempt to force settlement at discounted rate problems with discovery process promotes dispute over information access emphasizes inequality of resources (attrition strategy) depositions can sometimes lead away from the truth (confusing the witnesses; strategizing) structure of discovery rules Rule 26 scope; sets out what is discoverable 26(a) mandatory disclosure (initial disclosures, experts, witnesses) 26(b) scope of discovery (any matter (not privileged) relevant to claim/defense of any party) Rules 27-36 devices of discovery Rule 37 sanctions (both compelling and preventing discovery) distinction between mandatory disclosure and discovery (see notes p.38 for more detail) fits into broader scheme how litigation proceeds after pleadings have been exchanged discovery planning conference [26(f) conference] 26(a)(1) initial disclosures (soon after planning conference) scheduling order [16(b)] here, the judge finally gets involved in the case after all this, discovery then begins discovery = what you produce in response to request from adversary; disclosure = what you voluntarily produce in compliance with 26(a) difference between what must be disclosed and what is discoverable note: disclosures still happen later in litigation: 26(a)(3) pretrial disclosures, until 30 days before trial discoverable materials party seeking discovery must show substantial need of materials in preparation of his case must also show that he is unable without undue hardship to obtain the substantial equivalent of the materials by other means exception: work-product of attorney is protected from discovery (see privileges section below) Chalick v. TO JURY" \f C \l "3"  [Rule 49(b)] questions put to jury, always accompanied by request for jury to come back with a general verdict individual questions arent dispositive jury has to answer all of them, and also return general verdict discretion of judge when answers are inconsistent with each other or with the general verdict JUDGMENT AS A MATTER OF LAW TC "JUDGMENT AS A MATTER OF LAW" \f C \l "3"  [Rule 50] if during trial a party has been fully heard on an issue, and there is no legally sufficient evidentiary basis for a reasonable jury to find for that party on that issue, ct may determine the issue against that party, may grant judgment as a matter of law against that party on claims dependent on that issue motions for JMOL can be made at any time before submission of case to jury see CB p.742 for timeline of when parties can make JMOL motions motions must specify judgment sought and law/facts on which movant is entitled to judgment most extreme method of control takes decisional power away from jury, gives to judge if judge grants JMOL, app ct applies de novo review (no weight to what trial ct held) question before the ct is purely a matter of law; regardless of whether JMOL granted before or after jury determined issue of fact, appellate review will be the same (can decide jury got it wrong; power to review questions of law) question of constitutionality 7th A preserves right to jury trial now settled (by practice if not by history) that JMOL is constitutional under 7th A if JMOL gives judges too much power to decide facts, then its got to be unconstitutional; but if theres very little power of judge to look at facts, then rule has little utility various formulas about the point below which a party may not fall (wrt persuasiveness of evidence) clear that this analysis requires judge to weigh the evidence to some extent our system denies this, though judge/jury, law/fact distinction two types of JMOL: 50(a) after party has been ( intervening change in the law general rule against allowing 60(b) motions simply b/c there been an intervening change in the law exception: ct applies 60(b)(6) any other reason justifying relief from the operation of the judgment special circumstances: ppl in the same accident; unjust to apply different rule of law to parties in the same accident more important reason: in a diversity case, fed cts supposed to apply state law since state of OK has told us that the substantive rule has changed, fed ct should now apply new state law this case is NOT generally followed more important: stability of judgment, finality of litigation Ackerman v. US brothers-in-law joined cases of citizenship revocation; trial ct revoked citizenship; one brother appealed, one didnt; appealing brother won the appeal; other brother brought 60(b)(6) motion but was DENIED calculated risk to not appeal, so tough luck one area where exceptions allowed: where are there ongoing relationships, perhaps because of a judgment or injunction Agostini v. Felton injunction preventing NYC from sending special ed teachers to parochial schools; gradual change in 1st A law expanding church-state interactions; 12 years later, 60(b)(5) motion to set aside injunction (no longer equitable to apply judgment) generally, intervening change in law doesnt impact original litigant change in law will apply to present parties, but wont effect judgment given to prior parties  II.
